Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Alfred University Calculus Initiative (AUCI) is a multi-faceted project that combines an innovative and distinctive curriculum with classroom transformation, video lessons and examples, online quizzes and homework, and web-based implementation into a comprehensive calculus experience. This project is informed by current research and trends in STEM education, which include engaging students with visual and online technology, creating an active learning environment in the classroom, and incorporating meaningful applications. The AUCI is developing a website from which users can access various course components from remote locations. To take advantage of the intrinsic portability of the course materials, the AUCI is forming partnerships with area school districts so that the course may be offered to high school students on their own campuses and for college credit.

The fundamental goal of the AUCI is to increase understanding and success in calculus and precalculus while maintaining the level of rigor and breadth required for post-calculus courses. One of the key ideas to achieving AUCI's goal is a fundamental re-ordering of calculus topics. The evaluation of this project focuses on student learning outcomes and success in first-year calculus courses as well as on student perceptions of and attitudes towards the course content and delivery methods. Since each component of the project is adaptable to suit nearly any STEM discipline, the research being conducted on the effects of its content and structure have the potential to be a valuable resource for those interested in new perspectives on teaching calculus and other STEM courses in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broad and sound foundations in precalculus and calculus are crucial to the success of STEM majors in both higher-level mathematics courses and other calculus-dependent courses. The Alfred University Calculus Initiative (AUCI) follows current trends in STEM education in that it engages students with visual technology, active learning, and meaningful applications, all within the context of a new and intuitive rearrangement of the traditional first-semester calculus course content. Since the reorganized curriculum of the AUCI reinforces the mutually dependent relationship between calculus and precalculus in the context of in-class activities and experiences, the AUCI promotes discovery, understanding, and deeper learning.

The AUCI is based on the flipped teaching model in that it delivers the course content on video and readings outside of the classroom, while it frees up substantial time for a more interactive classroom environment focused on active learning rather than passive listening. At the time of initial funding, the main course materials were created, which include a new textbook, classroom activities, lesson videos, and online quiz and homework sets. Frequent formative and summative assessment informed subsequent editing of these materials. Current versions of the lessons, activities, and videos are open-source and can be accessed from the AUCI website.  

The major aspects of the evaluation plan for the AUCI focused on learning outcomes and overall success in first-year calculus courses. In particular, we sought to compare the AUCI with the traditional approach by tracking failure (DFW) rates, final exam grades, and student perceptions of and attitudes toward the course content and the delivery method. In all categories, the AUCI has significantly exceeded expectations. (For instance, the decrease in failure rate in first-semester calculus was over five times the anticipated measurable outcome.) By improving students’ experiences and success in this so-called STEM “gateway” course, the AUCI has ultimately led to higher first-year retention rates within the STEM disciplines on the Alfred University campus. A paper containing major results of the AUCI is currently under review.

Through its web-based implementation, the AUCI has the capacity to reach a wider audience. One example of this outreach is through the AUCI High School Program. Through this program, high school teachers facilitate the AUCI course from their own campuses while students access course materials online. The high school program provides students with an attractive alternative to AP or other placement credit by giving them the opportunity to earn real college credit for first-semester calculus without having to leave their own campuses. Teachers who facilitate the program gain valuable experience with the flipped teaching model which, in turn, enhances professional development. Currently, the high school program is available to high school students in selected counties of western New York.
